metadata.synopsis: In this tale of a killer canine, man's best friend turns into his worst enemy. When sweet St. Bernard Cujo is bitten by a bat, he starts behaving oddly and becomes very aggressive. As Cujo morphs into a dangerous beast, he goes on a rampage in a small town. Stay-at-home mom Donna (Dee Wallace) gets caught in Cujo's crosshairs on a fateful errand with her son, Tad (Danny Pintauro). Stuck in their tiny car, Donna and Tad have a frightening showdown with the crazed animal.

reviews: At certain moments, it's as if flawed individuals are met with toothy reprisal in a twisted form of justice - where survival defines worth.
It's a stripped-down nerve-shredder of a movie that has a bite every bit as potent as its bark.
The story gets lost in long and dull explanations. [Full Review in Spanish]
The movie is as nasty and single-minded as Cujo himself: It's simple, and it works.
A claustrophobic horror with plenty of bite.
Despite its apparent simplicity, Cujo actually expects more from its audience than the average nature amok thriller and even many of King's more successful stories.
"Cujo" no doubt presented fewer difficulties for a novelist than it does for a movie director.
'80s horror movie has some gore, lots of peril.
Wallace's turn will not be denied, and fans of real horror will recognize the greatness in her work here.
A horror film worthy of its classic status...
A dull, uneventful entry in the horror genre.
As thrilling and scary as Cujo can be, it's dreadful for long stretches.
Directed by Lewis Teague with less cinematographic flair than even the TV miniseries for 'Salem's Lot, Cujo unfortunately demonstrates the difficulty in adapting King's shorter works.
This adaptation on a modest budget from Stephen King's bestseller about a rabid St Bernard is a pleasing illustration of the filmic simplicity at the heart of King's better writing.
...there's no denying that the sequences dealing with Cujo's assault on Wallace's cheap Pinto are extremely effective...
